justification: The article notes that “cosine similarity between word vectors correlates with Likert-scale judgments of words’ similarity and relatedness (Richie & Bhatia, 2020; Hill et al., 2015).”

measured_by: reaction times in the lexical decision task
justification: It states that the same cosine similarity metric “correlates with … strength of semantic priming in, e.g., the lexical decision task, as measured by reaction times (Jones et al., 2006; Mandera et al., 2017).”
The text reports correlations “even with probability of recall given a cue in free association, or given an earlier recalled item in list recall.”

For the McRae et al. (2005) dataset, “Participants … were asked to list the features of each of the concepts…,” indicating that concept features are gathered through a feature-listing norming procedure.
The authors evaluate their model on “typicality ratings for concepts and categories,” explicitly treating such ratings as the empirical measure of conceptual typicality.
